'''Freddie Spruell''' (December 28, 1893 – June 19, 1956) was an [[United States|American]] [[Delta blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[singing|singer]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Weenie"/>

He was variously billed as '''Papa Freddie''' or '''Mr. Freddie''', and he is generally regarded as the first Delta bluesman to be recorded ("Milk Cow Blues", 1926). However, both [[Mamie Smith]] (1920) and [[Blind Lemon Jefferson]] (1925), pre-dated him in waxing the first 'blues' records.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p475029/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Freddie Spruell |author=Steve Leggett |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> Details of his life are sketchy and sometimes contradictory.

==Biography==
Spruell was probably born in [[Lake Providence, Louisiana]], [[United States]],<ref name="Gioia">{{cite book
| first= Ted
| last= Gioia
| year= 2008
| title= Delta Blues: The Life and Times of the Mississippi Masters Who Revolutionized American Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[W. W. Norton & Company|W. W. Norton & Company, Inc.]] 
| location= [[New York City|New York]]
| isbn= 978-0-393-06258-8
| page= 54}}</ref> but relocated with his family to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], as a small child. His Social Security records gave his birth date as December 1893. His [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]], although classed as Delta blues, were noted for reasons of his musical styling, rather than any geographical accuracy regarding his long-time place of residence.<ref name="AMG"/>

On June 25, 1926, Spruell cut "Milk Cow Blues" in Chicago. The track was released by [[Okeh Records]], alongside "Muddy Water Blues" which was recorded in November that year, both sides using the Papa Freddie name.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Wirz">{{cite web |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/spruefrm.htm |title=Freddie Spruell discography |author=Stefan Wirz |date= |work= |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> His second [[Single (music)|single]] release included "Way Back Down Home" and the same "Muddy Water Blues" track.<ref name="Wirz"/> He recorded two more songs in 1928, one of which was "Tom Cat Blues", and were issued by [[Paramount Records]] as by Mr. Freddie Spruell. Five further songs were recorded in April 1935, and released under the shorter Mr. Freddie name on the [[Bluebird Records]] label. This latter recording session saw him cut "Let's Go Riding", his best known number. [[Carl Martin (musician)|Carl Martin]] played second guitar behind Spruell, on the track.<ref name="AMG"/>

At the insistence of his own mother, Spruell's playing of secular music ended in the mid-1940s, and he became a [[Baptists|Baptist]] [[preacher]].<ref name="Weenie"/>

Spruell died in Chicago in June 1956, after a lengthy stay in hospital. He was aged 62. However, no death certificate has yet been uncovered.<ref name="Weenie">{{cite web |url=http://weeniecampbell.com/yabbse/index.php?topic=2477.0 |title=Freddie Spruell |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Weeniecampbell.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref>

All his recorded work was included in the [[compilation album]], ''Mississippi Blues: Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 2 (1926-1935)''.<ref name="Album"/>

==Legacy==
"Let's Go Riding" was featured in the [[soundtrack]] of the 2001 [[film]], ''[[Ghost World (film)|Ghost World]]''.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Discography==

===Compilation album===
*''Mississippi Blues: Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 2 (1926-1935)'' (1994) - [[Document Records]]<ref name="Album">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=mississippi-blues-complete-recorded-works-vol-2-1926-1935-r253563/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Mississippi Blues: Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 2 (1926-1935)'' > Review )))}}</ref>
